Other governments, notably those of Italy and Britain, have moved
to limit and control the promotion of cigarettes in their countries. With
some 4,500 American youngsters between the ages of 12 and 17 taking
up the smoking habit every day. isn't it time that the United States
followed the example of these other countries in protecting their youth?
As cacets here at PMC, we are well aware of the practice of dio-
tributing sample packs of cigarettes. The weekly gifts of cigarettes
found under our plates in the mess hall are part of life at PMC and
techniques of cigarette advertisers through their work on our own
are looked for with great anticipation each week. We know well the
campus which is probably more intensified than on other campuses.
The neveral vending machines are a familiar sight scatterea around
our campus. Most cadets realize what it is like to be without a cigarette
and lacking change to buy a pack. Mont of us have experienced this
agony relieved only by the inhalation of tobacco smoke. Most of us also
realize the expense that this habit has cost us over the years, money
whirh could have paid a good part of our tuition or bought items or
